dealer.overview: You are part of the Club Staff - a coordinated team of Dealers working to take control of the party. Your goal is to eliminate Party Animals until you equal or outnumber them.
dealer.earlyGame: Stay quiet and blend in. Vote with the majority to avoid suspicion. Coordinate with fellow Dealers during night kills - choose targets who might investigate you (Bouncer, Bartender) or protect others (Medic, Sober). Don't be afraid to bus a fellow Dealer if it builds your credibility.
dealer.lateGame: As numbers dwindle, you can be more aggressive. If you've built trust, use it to misdirect votes. Watch out for the Minor - they're immune to your kills until the Bouncer IDs them. Protect your Silver Fox and Whore if alive - they're your best defensive tools.
dos: Vote with the majority early to build innocent credibility
Target investigators (Bouncer, Bartender) on early nights
Bus a teammate if the heat gets too close — sacrifice one to save many
Keep mental notes on who claims what role and when
Coordinate kill targets with fellow Dealers during night phase
donts: Never be the first to accuse someone without evidence — it draws suspicion
Don't kill the loudest player — they're often vanilla and their death reveals nothing
Avoid voting as a bloc with other Dealers — stagger your votes
Don't panic-claim a power role when pressured — it's verifiable
Never ignore the Medic — an alive Medic undoes your kills
Don't target the same player as the Roofi - if Roofi targets you, your kill is blocked
deceptionTactics: Fake-claim Bartender and report fabricated alignment checks to frame innocents
Echo town suspicions slightly louder to seem analytical without leading
When a teammate is caught, be the first to vote them — it cements your cover
Create pocket allies by defending one confirmed innocent aggressively
Seed doubt with 'just asking questions' — never accuse directly
betrayalAdvice: Bus your weakest Dealer link when they're already suspect — you gain massive credibility
If a Dealer teammate claims a role, subtly cast doubt to get them exiled — fewer Dealers means less suspicion on you
Use the night kill to eliminate players who trust you most — it deflects suspicion elsewhere
Coordinate a 'fake split' with another Dealer where you publicly disagree to seem independent

bouncer.overview: You are the Party Animals' primary investigator. Each night you can ID one player to learn if they're Club Staff or clean. Results are revealed privately to you in the morning.
bouncer.earlyGame: Start by checking players who are unusually quiet or deflecting suspicion. Build a list of cleared players in your mind. Don't claim Bouncer immediately - wait until you have actionable information (found a Dealer) or need to save a cleared player from being voted out.
bouncer.lateGame: Once you've claimed, coordinate with the Medic for protection. Be aware that Roofi can revoke your ability permanently, and Ally Cat witnesses your checks (though they can only communicate in 'Meow'). If you ID the Minor, they become vulnerable to Dealer kills - use this strategically.
dos: Check the most active deflectors first — Dealers manipulate conversations
Breadcrumb your results to trusted allies before claiming publicly
Coordinate with Medic once you claim — you are target #1
Use your cleared list to build a voting coalition
Check players who seem 'too helpful' — Dealers overcompensate
donts: Don't claim Bouncer on Day 1 with no results — you become an instant kill target
Never reveal all your checked players at once — it gives Dealers a hit list
Don't ignore the Silver Fox — their alibis can make your checks look wrong
Avoid checking confirmed vanilla players — it wastes precious nights
Don't ID the Minor unless strategically necessary — it removes their immunity
deceptionTactics: Withhold one clear result and reveal it later to test if someone contradicts your info
Announce you're checking someone specific tonight to bait the Dealers into avoiding that kill
Feed slightly delayed info to see who reacts suspiciously to 'leaked' results
betrayalAdvice: If you find a Dealer, sit on the info for one round to observe who they coordinate with
Publicly clear a player you suspect is the Whore's scapegoat — when they're exiled, the Whore loses their shield
Use your credibility to push an exile on a quiet player who's actually a Dealer's silent partner

medic.overview: You make the most critical decision at game start: choose daily protection OR a one-time revive. This choice is permanent and visible to all players.
medic.earlyGame: PROTECTION MODE: Each night, choose someone to save from Dealer kills (you cannot protect yourself). Prioritize confirmed investigators or the Bouncer once claimed. REVIVE MODE: Wait for a high-value player to die (confirmed Bouncer, multiple-life roles, or a Dealer kill that confirms alliance). Don't waste your token on a voted-out player who might have been guilty.
medic.lateGame: Protection mode becomes predictable - Dealers may avoid your target and kill elsewhere. Consider protecting less obvious players to maximize coverage. Revive mode timing is everything - a late-game resurrection can swing the win, but waiting too long means you might die with the token unused.
dos: Protect the claimed Bouncer every night once they reveal
Switch protection targets unpredictably if no one has claimed
Self-protect on Night 1 if the game feels aggressive
Save your revive for a confirmed power role death
Coordinate secretly with your protection target
donts: Don't waste your revive on a player exiled by vote — they might be guilty
Never protect the same player every single night — Dealers will figure it out
Don't claim Medic early unless absolutely necessary — it paints a target
Avoid using revive on Night 1 deaths — you don't have enough info yet
Don't protect someone who's already been ID'd as a Dealer
deceptionTactics: Publicly hint you're protecting someone you're NOT to bait Dealers into attacking that player
If in Revive mode, act like you chose Protection to keep Dealers guessing
Claim to have protected a dead player to gauge reactions — if someone seems relieved, they might be a Dealer
betrayalAdvice: If you suspect the claimed Bouncer is fake, stop protecting them and see what happens overnight
Use protection as leverage — offer to protect someone in exchange for voting intel
Let a suspected Dealer ally die to confirm they were innocent, then use the data

creep.overview: You are a neutral role with a unique mechanic: on Night 0, select a target. You immediately adopt their alliance and win with their team. When your target dies, you inherit their exact role.
creep.earlyGame: Target selection is CRITICAL. Choose someone likely to survive (avoid Dealers, high-profile investigators). Consider roles with powerful abilities (Bouncer, Predator, Drama Queen) or multiple lives (Seasoned Drinker, Ally Cat). Once selected, you must play as if you ARE that alliance - your win condition is now tied to them.
creep.lateGame: If your target is still alive, continue supporting their team quietly. If they die and you inherit their role, you must instantly adopt their behaviour patterns. Study your target throughout the game - know how they vote, who they trust, what claims they've made. The inheritance should feel seamless to other players.
dos: Pick a target likely to survive past Night 2 — low-profile players are safest
Study your target's voting patterns and social connections
Play as your adopted alliance from the very first discussion phase
If you inherit a role, use the ability immediately — delays look suspicious
Consider targeting multi-life roles for maximum value
donts: Don't pick a Dealer — you'll be outnumbered and hunted
Never reveal you're the Creep — no one trusts a chameleon
Don't copy your target's behaviour too closely — be natural, not a mirror
Avoid targeting the Bouncer — they're the most likely to be killed early
Don't wait too long to use inherited abilities — the game won't wait for you
deceptionTactics: Claim vanilla Party Animal and fly under the radar until inheritance triggers
When you inherit, pretend you've had the role all along — fabricate past results if needed
Use your knowledge of your target's behaviour to seamlessly replace them in alliances
betrayalAdvice: If your target turns out to be a Dealer, lean into it — you now win with Club Staff
Use your unique position of knowing exactly who your target was to manipulate both sides
If your target is exiled, inherit their role and claim they told you their info before dying

minor.overview: You are a Party Animal with a unique defence: completely immune to Dealer kills UNTIL the Bouncer IDs you. Once ID'd, you become vulnerable. You can still be voted out.
minor.earlyGame: Your immunity makes you bold, but don't reveal your role or the Bouncer may feel pressured to check you 'just to enable kills' if the town becomes desperate. Blend in as a regular Party Animal. Push suspicion onto others - you can't be night-killed, so Dealers may avoid you naturally.
minor.lateGame: If the Bouncer has claimed, ask privately or publicly if they've checked you - if not, you have guaranteed survival from night kills. This makes you an excellent vote leader. However, once ID'd, protect yourself through social capital and vote manipulation. Note: Only Dealer kills are blocked - Predator revenge and votes still work.
dos: Be vocal and aggressive in debates — you can afford the attention
Lead vote pushes against suspected Dealers — they literally can't kill you at night
Use your immunity to draw Dealer kill attempts that waste their night action
Build alliances with confirmed investigators to amplify their findings
Push for information shares during the day — you're the safest messenger
donts: Never reveal you're the Minor — it changes Bouncer priorities and Dealer strategy
Don't assume you're fully immune — votes and Predator revenge still kill you
Avoid pressuring the Bouncer to check you — it removes your best defence
Don't get complacent — social reads matter more than night immunity
Never forget that once ID'd, you become a regular target overnight
deceptionTactics: Act nervous about being night-killed to maintain the illusion you're vulnerable
Claim a different role if pressured — Sober or Bartender are safe bluffs
Use your safety to take risks others can't — push aggressive reads and see who flinches
betrayalAdvice: If the town is losing, reveal your immunity to rally the remaining Party Animals
Use your unkillable status to bait Dealers into wasting kills — then publicly note 'I survived the night'
Frame a Dealer by claiming they 'targeted you last night' knowing you survived

party_animal.overview: You are a vanilla Party Animal with no special ability. Your strength is in social deduction, voting, and blending in.
party_animal.earlyGame: Watch voting patterns and player behaviour. Ask questions and pressure suspicious players. You have nothing to hide, so you can be aggressive without fear of investigation.
party_animal.lateGame: Use your confirmed vanilla status (if claimed) to build trust. Lead voting coalitions and protect power roles.
dos: Ask pointed questions during every discussion phase — information is your weapon
Track who votes with whom across multiple rounds
Claim vanilla early if it helps power roles stay hidden
Build voting coalitions with 2-3 trusted players
Be the loudest voice against suspected Dealers — you have nothing to lose
donts: Don't stay silent — quiet vanilla players get mislynched or killed for being unhelpful
Never fake-claim a power role — it wastes the town's time and trust
Don't blindly follow vote trains — analyse before committing
Avoid tunnel-visioning on one suspect — Dealers work in teams
Don't ignore voting patterns — they're your best deduction tool
deceptionTactics: Pretend to have secret information to bait Dealer reactions during discussion
Act like you know more than you do — Dealers will try to silence confident players
Use reverse psychology: defend someone to see if Dealers pile on or back off
betrayalAdvice: If a 'confirmed' player starts acting suspicious, don't be afraid to turn on them publicly
Use your lack of ability as freedom — you can accuse anyone without revealing mechanics
Rally votes against the player who seems most 'safe' — Dealers love hiding behind trust

whore.overview: You are Club Staff with a powerful one-time ability: deflect the day vote away from yourself to another player. Use this to survive a critical vote.
whore.earlyGame: Save your deflection for when you're genuinely under pressure. Don't waste it on a single vote - wait until you're clearly about to be exiled.
whore.lateGame: Your deflection can swing the game if timed perfectly. Coordinate with other Dealers to ensure your deflection target is beneficial.
dos: Save your deflection for when exile is guaranteed — timing is everything
Choose a deflection target who is genuinely suspicious to sell the redirect
Build trust as a Party Animal early so your survival seems natural
Coordinate with Dealers to set up your deflection target in advance
After deflecting, immediately shift the narrative — 'See? I told you it was them!'
donts: Don't deflect too early — you only get one shot
Never deflect onto a confirmed innocent — it looks obvious and desperate
Don't reveal your role to other Dealers unless absolutely necessary
Avoid drawing attention before you've used your ability
Don't waste your deflection on a vote you might survive naturally
deceptionTactics: Build a long-term case against your intended deflection target days before you need to use it
Fake-claim Sober or Bartender to explain away any suspicious connections
When deflecting, act shocked — 'Wait, the votes shifted? What's happening?'
Pre-seed distrust against your scapegoat by asking 'innocent questions' about them
betrayalAdvice: Deflect onto the Dealer who's most likely to be caught anyway — you gain credibility AND remove a weak link
If another Dealer is under pressure, let them take the fall — save your deflection for yourself
Use the chaos of your deflection to push a second vote against a power role

silver_fox.overview: You are Club Staff with the ability to grant nightly alibis, creating confusion and protecting teammates from investigation.
silver_fox.earlyGame: Use your ability to shield fellow Dealers or create false investigation results.
silver_fox.lateGame: Your alibi grants become more valuable as investigators narrow down suspects.
dos: Alibi your fellow Dealers to corrupt Bouncer ID checks
Occasionally alibi an innocent to make your pattern unpredictable
Keep track of who the Bouncer has checked so you know where to alibi
Alibi yourself if you suspect the Bouncer is checking you tonight
Use alibis to create trust — alibi'd players look innocent
donts: Don't only alibi Dealers — the pattern becomes obvious
Never admit you're the Silver Fox — your power relies on secrecy
Don't alibi dead players — it wastes your action and looks suspicious in retrospect
Avoid alibiing the same player multiple nights — it's traceable
Don't ignore the Bartender — their alignment checks bypass your alibis differently
deceptionTactics: Alibi a vocal innocent to make the Bouncer's check read them as 'clean' — then claim THEY are the suspicious one
Create a narrative where your alibi'd Dealer seems confirmed-innocent through 'independent' checks
If caught, claim you're the Sober who 'sent someone home' — the mechanics overlap in reports
betrayalAdvice: Stop alibiing a Dealer teammate if they're about to be caught — let them fall cleanly
Alibi a Party Animal power role to make them trust you, then use that trust to misdirect votes
Use your alibis to protect yourself over teammates when the endgame approaches

roofi.overview: You silence a player (preventing their night action) and block one Dealer kill attempt. If you target the ONLY living Dealer, their kill is completely blocked.
roofi.earlyGame: Silence suspicious players to block their night actions. Use your kill-block strategically to save confirmed town.
roofi.lateGame: Revoking Bouncer's ability is a huge decision. If only one Dealer remains, targeting them stops all kills for the night.
dos: Silence the most suspicious player each night to test your reads
Save your kill-block for when you're confident a Dealer is about to strike
Coordinate with the Bouncer — silence players they haven't checked yet
Use silence to protect power roles indirectly by blocking attackers
Track which players had no night report after you silenced them — they had an action to block
Target the suspected final Dealer to block their kill
donts: Don't revoke the Bouncer unless you're absolutely certain they're compromised
Never waste your silence on confirmed innocent vanilla players
Don't silence the same player two nights in a row without strong evidence
Avoid claiming Roofi too early — Dealers will kill you immediately
Don't forget that silenced players can't use ANY ability — including protective ones
deceptionTactics: Announce you silenced someone and watch for the player who seems relieved vs frustrated
Claim to have blocked a kill when you actually silenced someone — gauge reactions
Use your silence results to build a case: 'I blocked them and no one died — coincidence?'
betrayalAdvice: If you silence someone and a kill still happens, you've confirmed they're NOT the Dealer — share this intel
Silence the Medic if you need an important kill to go through for the greater good of deduction
Use your information advantage — you know exactly who couldn't act last night

sober.overview: You can send one player home each night, making them immune to night actions (both harmful and helpful) AND blocking their own action.
sober.earlyGame: Protect vulnerable players or block suspicious actions. Your targets are safe from kills but also can't be investigated or protected.
sober.lateGame: Coordinate with Medic to avoid overlapping protection. Use strategically to block suspected Dealer kills.
dos: Send home suspected Dealer kill targets to waste the Dealers' night
Protect power roles who haven't claimed yet by sending them home
Coordinate with the Medic so you don't overlap protection on the same player
Send home the Bouncer on nights they're not checking — it's free protection
Use your power to test reads — send someone home and see if a kill still happens
Send home a suspected killer to block their attack
donts: Don't send home the Bouncer when they need to investigate — it blocks their check
Never send home the same player every night — Dealers will redirect
Don't forget that your target also can't be HELPED — no Medic save, no alibi
Avoid sending home confirmed Dealers — they can't be killed at night anyway
Don't send yourself home — you can't self-target
deceptionTactics: Publicly say you're sending someone home to bait Dealers into targeting a different player
Claim to have sent home someone who died — 'I didn't send them home, so I was testing elsewhere'
Use your power as a bargaining chip in daytime discussions
betrayalAdvice: If you suspect the Bouncer is fake-claiming, send them home to waste their 'investigation' and test the theory
Send home a player who's about to be checked by Bouncer if you suspect the Bouncer is a Dealer
Use your data to call out inconsistencies — 'I sent X home and a kill still happened in their direction? Someone's lying.'

wallflower.overview: You witness Dealer murders at night. This role is REQUIRED in every game - if not selected, one Party Animal becomes the Wallflower.
wallflower.earlyGame: You learn who was killed by Dealers (not vote exiles or other deaths). Use this to track Dealer activity patterns.
wallflower.lateGame: Your information confirms kills happened, helping distinguish between Dealer kills, Predator revenge, and vote exiles.
dos: Memorize every face you see during the murder phase
Wait for the right moment to reveal your witness testimony — timing is everything
Cross-reference your sightings with who claims what during the day
Use your information to validate or discredit Bouncer claims
Stay alive as long as possible — you're the only eyewitness
donts: Don't reveal immediately what you saw — Dealers will kill you next night
Never claim Wallflower without actionable evidence — it makes you a target for nothing
Don't confuse vote-exiled players with Dealer kills — you only witness murders
Avoid being too vocal about night events — Dealers will figure out you're watching
Don't panic-reveal after Night 1 — build your case over multiple nights
deceptionTactics: Drop subtle hints about what you saw without revealing your role
Claim to have 'heard something' or 'noticed a pattern' to introduce your evidence indirectly
Wait until two sightings confirm a pattern before making your move
betrayalAdvice: If you witness a kill and recognize the victim, use it to rally votes without revealing how you know
Reveal your Wallflower status only when your testimony can seal an exile — one shot, one kill
If the Bouncer's claims conflict with your sightings, call it out publicly

ally_cat.overview: You have 9 lives, witness Bouncer ID checks, and can ONLY speak in 'Meow'. A challenging but powerful investigative role.
ally_cat.earlyGame: Watch Bouncer checks carefully. Your meow-only communication makes sharing information nearly impossible, so focus on voting patterns.
ally_cat.lateGame: Your 9 lives make you nearly unkillable by Dealers. Use this to be aggressive in voting. Creative meowing ('Meow meow MEOW') can sometimes convey urgency.
dos: Use your votes as your primary communication — vote aggressively on suspected Dealers
Stay alive and draw Dealer kills — your 9 lives are a shield for the entire town
Watch the Bouncer's checks and use urgent meowing to signal when they find something
Use vote timing to communicate — early confident votes signal certainty
Protect the Bouncer by being their bodyguard — sit near them in discussions
donts: Don't try to spell words with meows — it wastes time and confuses everyone
Never forget you can still be vote-exiled — meow-only makes defence nearly impossible
Don't waste lives being reckless — 9 lives is a lot, but not infinite
Avoid drawing Predator attention — their revenge kill bypasses your lives differently
Don't ignore your Bouncer surveillance duty — it's your most valuable asset
deceptionTactics: Use different meow intensities to signal danger levels — train your allies to read you
Meow at specific players to draw attention to them — your accusation is your vote
Intentionally vote first to lead the discussion without words
betrayalAdvice: If the Bouncer finds a Dealer, immediately switch your vote — others will follow your lead
Tank Dealer kills on purpose by being vocal (meowing loudly) — each wasted kill is a win
Use your near-invincibility to force votes — pile on and dare others to follow

seasoned_drinker.overview: You have extra lives equal to the number of Dealers in the game. These lives ONLY absorb Dealer kills - votes and other kill sources bypass them.
seasoned_drinker.earlyGame: Be bold! You can survive multiple Dealer attacks. Use your tankiness to draw kills away from power roles.
seasoned_drinker.lateGame: As Dealers die, your effective HP goes down (if you lose lives). Other players can see your life count, so they know when you're vulnerable.
dos: Be loud and confrontational — draw Dealer kills to yourself
Use your visible life count as proof you've been targeted — 'They tried to kill me last night'
Shield power roles by making yourself a more tempting target
Track your life loss to count how many Dealer kills have happened
Pair with the Medic for maximum survivability
donts: Don't forget your lives only block DEALER kills — votes and Predator bypass them
Never assume you're safe — your life count is public and Dealers can strategize around it
Don't waste your tankiness by being quiet — if they don't attack you, your lives are wasted
Avoid being so aggressive that you get vote-exiled instead of night-killed
Don't ignore that your life count reveals information about Dealer activity
deceptionTactics: Claim a power role to force Dealers to spend kills on you instead of actual power roles
Announce 'I lost a life last night' to confirm Dealer activity without revealing your exact status
Use your tanky reputation to negotiate — 'Protect someone else, Medic, I can handle myself'
betrayalAdvice: If you're losing lives fast, publicly count them to put pressure on Dealer hunters
Use your survival as evidence — 'I've survived three nights, clearly the Dealers are targeting me for a reason'
Tank kills to buy time for investigators, then use your survival data to push final exiles

lightweight.overview: Each night you choose a player who becomes permanently unvotable for you. Your voting pool shrinks each round, forcing you to think strategically about who you eliminate from your options.
lightweight.earlyGame: Target players you're fairly confident are innocent early on. Removing confirmed Party Animals from your vote pool means your remaining votes are more likely to land on Dealers. Pay attention to Bouncer claims and early reads.
lightweight.lateGame: With fewer voting options remaining, every vote counts. If you've been strategic, your remaining targets should include the most suspicious players. Use your restricted pool as implicit information — you know who you can't vote for, so focus your arguments on those you still can.
dos: Block players you're confident are innocent — this narrows your votes toward Dealers
Coordinate with investigators to confirm who is safe before locking them out
Use your shrinking pool as a strategic advantage — fewer options means more focused pressure
Pay close attention to role claims and voting patterns before choosing your nightly target
Keep a mental map of who you can and can't vote for as the game progresses
donts: Don't block suspicious players — you want to keep them votable
Never block a player too early without good reason — you can't undo it
Don't reveal which players you've blocked unless it helps your argument
Avoid blocking all players on one side — you need flexibility
Don't forget to check your blocked list before voting — wasted votes help Dealers
deceptionTactics: Claim you blocked a Dealer suspect to seem proactive — even if you actually blocked an innocent
Use your restriction as cover for not voting against certain players — 'I literally can't vote for them'
Publicly announce strategic blocks to build trust with the Party Animals
betrayalAdvice: If investigators confirm a player as Staff, make sure you haven't blocked them — adjust your nightly picks accordingly
Use your blocked list as evidence of good reads — 'I blocked all the confirmed innocents, my remaining options are the killers'
In endgame, your restricted pool can be powerful proof of alignment — share it to rally final votes

tea_spiller.overview: When you die, one random person who voted for you has their role revealed to everyone.
tea_spiller.earlyGame: This is a passive ability. You might want to claim it to discourage votes, or hide it to catch Dealers who vote you.
tea_spiller.lateGame: Your death can provide crucial information. Sometimes sacrificing yourself to reveal a voter is worth it.
dos: Consider claiming Tea Spiller to discourage Dealer votes against you
Track who votes for you in every round — one of them will be exposed
Use your death as a weapon — if you're going down, make sure Dealers voted for you
Build trust by offering to be voted out if the town is desperate for information
Make sure multiple people vote for you to maximize the chance of exposing a Dealer
donts: Don't claim too early — it might make Dealers avoid voting you entirely
Never forget your ability is RANDOM — you can't choose who gets revealed
Don't sacrifice yourself unless multiple Dealers voted for you
Avoid getting killed at night — you need to be VOTED out for your ability to trigger
Don't let fear of dying prevent you from being useful during discussions
deceptionTactics: Threaten to reveal your role to force Dealers to abstain from voting you
Act expendable to bait more votes — the more people vote, the better your odds
Claim you have 'a secret that activates on death' without specifying Tea Spiller
betrayalAdvice: If the town needs data, volunteer as tribute — your death reveals truth
Force a split vote where you're one of the targets to guarantee information flow
Use the threat of your ability to control voting patterns and flush out Dealer coordination

predator.overview: When you die, you kill one player of your choice as revenge. This is a one-time reactive ability.
predator.earlyGame: Don't claim this role - it makes you a prime target for votes instead of night kills (to control who you revenge-kill).
predator.lateGame: Once revealed or about to die, choose your revenge target wisely. Kill a confirmed Dealer if possible.
dos: Keep your role secret as long as possible — it's your trump card
Build a mental kill list — know exactly who you'd revenge-kill at any moment
Pay attention to who's confirmed as a Dealer so your revenge is guaranteed value
Consider revealing when you're about to be night-killed to deter Dealers
Use your impending death to negotiate — 'Kill me and I take your partner'
donts: Don't reveal Predator early — Dealers will vote-exile you to control your revenge target timing
Never waste your revenge on a vanilla player — always target suspected or confirmed Dealers
Don't forget you can be blocked by Roofi — if silenced, your revenge might not trigger
Avoid being too quiet — you need information to choose the best revenge target
Don't panic-reveal when pressured — sometimes dying quietly with a pre-planned target is better
deceptionTactics: Claim a different role entirely to avoid vote manipulation around your death
When you suspect you'll die tonight, announce 'I know who the Dealer is' — they might change targets
Use the threat of your revenge kill to extract confessions during heated discussions
betrayalAdvice: If you're certain about a Dealer, tell the town 'Even if I die, I'll take them with me' to confirm your read
Negotiate with Dealers — 'Kill me and I'll revenge-kill a Party Animal' (then don't)
Use your death sentence as ultimate leverage — no one wants to trigger your revenge

drama_queen.overview: When you die, randomly swap the roles of two living players. This is one of the most chaotic abilities in the game.
drama_queen.earlyGame: This is a passive death trigger. Consider claiming to make Dealers afraid to kill you at night.
drama_queen.lateGame: Your death can completely change the game state. A well-timed swap can turn a Dealer into the Bouncer or vice versa.
dos: Claim Drama Queen to discourage Dealer kills — they don't want random chaos
Stay alive as long as possible to maximize the disruption potential
Study who holds which role so you can predict what swaps would be devastating
Use the threat of your swap to control the game's pace
If you're going to die, try to time it when a swap would benefit Party Animals
donts: Don't forget the swap is RANDOM — you can't choose who gets swapped
Never sacrifice yourself hoping for a good swap — the odds are unpredictable
Don't claim Drama Queen if Dealers would benefit from a random swap
Avoid dying when few players remain — the swap affects a larger percentage of roles
Don't let the chaos potential make you reckless with your own survival
deceptionTactics: Claim Drama Queen even if you're not to deter night kills (risky if actual Drama Queen exists)
Announce 'Kill me and watch the chaos' to force Dealers to target someone else
Use fear of the swap to delay exiles and buy time for investigators
betrayalAdvice: If the game is going badly for Party Animals, volunteer for exile — the chaos might reset the balance
Use your death as a wild card — even Dealers don't want unpredictable role swaps
Threaten to reveal all your information before dying, then let the swap handle the rest

bartender.overview: Each night, select two players. You learn if they are on the same team (aligned) or different teams. Results are revealed privately to you in the morning.
bartender.earlyGame: Check pairs of suspicious players. If they're aligned and one flips Dealer, you've found two. Check suspected Dealers against confirmed town.
bartender.lateGame: Your alignment checks become more valuable as you narrow down suspects. Coordinate with Bouncer to cross-reference findings.
dos: Check one suspected Dealer against one confirmed innocent — if they're misaligned, you have a lead
Cross-reference your alignment data with Bouncer results for double confirmation
Check players who vote together often — Dealers coordinate subtly
Build a web of connections: if A aligns with B and B aligns with C, A aligns with C
Share results carefully — too much info makes you a priority kill target
donts: Don't check two confirmed innocents — it wastes your night action
Never reveal all your results at once — Dealers will kill you and discredit your findings
Don't forget Silver Fox alibis can corrupt your results
Avoid checking dead players — they can't be checked
Don't ignore vote patterns — use alignment checks to confirm behavioural suspicions
deceptionTactics: Withhold one key alignment result to use as a bombshell during a critical vote
Announce you're checking two specific players to bait Silver Fox into alibiing one of them
Use partial results to create a narrative — 'These two are aligned, and one of them is definitely lying'
betrayalAdvice: If your results conflict with the Bouncer's, someone is being manipulated by Silver Fox — figure out who
Use your alignment web to identify the Silver Fox specifically — they'll always alibi Dealers
Save your most damning result for the final vote — drop it when it can't be disputed

messy_bitch.overview: You are a neutral role that wins SOLO if all living players have a rumour. Each night you spread one rumour which appears as a public teaser in the morning feed.
messy_bitch.earlyGame: Spread rumours strategically. Prioritize players likely to survive. You win alone, so both teams are your enemy once they realize your goal.
messy_bitch.lateGame: As players die, your win condition gets easier (fewer targets to rumour). Balance spreading chaos without painting a target on yourself.
dos: Rumour the players most likely to survive — Medic-protected, multi-life, or town leaders
Spread chaos during discussions to distract from your true win condition
Keep your solo win condition secret as long as possible
Prioritize rumoring players on the WINNING side — they'll survive longest
Use the rumour mechanic to your advantage: players with rumours become discussion topics
donts: Don't reveal you're the Messy Bitch — both teams will exile you immediately

club_manager.overview: You are a neutral role that can view one player's role card each night. Your goal is simply to survive until the end - you win with whoever wins.
club_manager.earlyGame: Gather information by viewing role cards. Use this to align with the winning team without revealing your neutrality.
club_manager.lateGame: Blend in with the majority team. Your survival is the only goal - you don't care who wins, as long as you're alive.
dos: Check the most influential players first — knowing their role lets you play both sides
Align yourself visibly with whichever team is winning

clinger.overview: You are obsessed with another player (your choice at game start). You MUST vote with them, and if they die, you die too. However, they can 'free' you as an Attack Dog, giving you independence and a kill.
clinger.earlyGame: Choose your partner wisely - pick someone likely to survive and whose judgment you trust. Your votes are locked to theirs.
clinger.lateGame: If freed as Attack Dog, use your kill strategically. If still clingy, protect your partner at all costs.
dos: Choose a partner who's likely to survive — Medic, Seasoned Drinker, or Minor are ideal
Follow your partner's lead in discussions and votes — you literally have no choice
Protect your partner with information and social capital

second_wind.overview: You START as a Party Animal. If Dealers try to kill you, you survive and they must decide next day: convert you to Club Staff or execute you. This is a convertible role.
second_wind.earlyGame: Play as a normal Party Animal. If you survive a Dealer kill, the game changes - you might become a Dealer or be executed.
second_wind.lateGame: If converted to Club Staff, your win condition flips instantly. You now want Dealers to win. This is incredibly powerful and chaotic.
